Communist capitalism has beaten democratic socialism so far. Link: https://indiadying.blogspot.com/2018/12/communist-capitalism-has-beaten.html

"China and India make up for two contrasting -- but fascinating -- case studies Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/gu4BCDRdaWedQNb8DhW5yL/Opinion--China-and-India-Struggling-to-rebalance.html of economic management in emerging economies," wrote R Malik. The two economies are completely different. "China, which is demand-constrained, is trying to cushion its structural deceleration, whereas India, which is supply-constrained, is struggling to unlock its potential for higher trend growth." Reforms started in 1978 in China, along with a one-child policy which reduced the number of births by 400 million Link: https://getrevising.co.uk/grids/chinas_one_child_policy_2 , improved health of women, reduced demand on environment for food production and decreased poverty, at the cost of erosion of human rights in forcing women to have abortions. Chinese leaders believe that growth is possible only by exercising total control on the people."They believe that they have their ears sufficiently to the ground, that they can remain responsive to any brewing discontent. They hope they can exercise social control through facial recognition Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/CuftLrC0pEUmMPexxGhYeO/Opinion--Chinas-boldest-experiment.html and other technologies that they have taken the lead in deploying," wrote Prof D Rodrik. While communist China embraced capitalism, Indira Gandhi inserted the word 'socialism' into the preamble of the Constitution Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forty-second_Amendment_of_the_Constitution_of_India in 1976, during the Emergency. But the socialist rot had started much earlier in 1973-74when the top rate of income tax was raised to 97.75% Link: https://www.indiatoday.in/business/budget/story/a-50-year-trend-of-indian-personal-tax-rates-129405-2011-02-26 . When the balance of payment crisis hit in 1991 India had to pawn 67 tons of gold to borrow Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1991_Indian_economic_crisis enough foreign exchange to fund imports. China undervalued the exchange rate of its currency to increase exports. "The disinflationary impact of its stepped-up supply-side and the ballooning of its current account surplus also facilitated a sustained downshift in the structure of local interest rates." "India's semi-functional 'do what you can, when you can' approach also has to make up for its relatively more progressive exchange rate policy that has shunned outright undervaluation of the currency." India always runs a current account deficit Link: https://www.domain-b.com/economy/general/20181210_current_account.html which could rise to 2.9% in this financial year. We have a trade deficit with our trading partners Link: https://www.bloombergquint.com/global-economics/indias-trade-deficit-narrows-in-august-to-1739-billion because we import more than we export. That is because our manufacturing as a share of the GDP has fallen to 16.2% Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/DnfWP2niBegPzUeZuhWfuO/Stagnant-manufacturing.html in 2015-16 from 16.41% in 1989-90, which was just before the crisis. We have to rely on a stronger rupee to control the cost of imports to keep inflation down and keep the current account deficit from jumping. China has insurance schemes for social welfare Link: https://www.hrone.com/guide-chinas-social-security-system-pays/ , where employers and employees contribute, whereas India has a long list of schemes Link: https://wordpandit.com/list-of-govt-schemes-in-india/ which are pure handouts. This necessitates a hunger forhigher tax collections resulting in extortionate demand Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/blogs/et-commentary/how-to-chase-away-fdi/ on businesses. That is why India's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is $2,135, while that of China is $10,000. Will India go up or will China fall down? Remains to be seen.

Will the RBI go from autonomy to supine? Link: https://indiadying.blogspot.com/2018/12/will-rbi-go-from-autonomy-to-supine.html

The Governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Urjit Patel resigned Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/banking/finance/banking/urjit-patel-resigns-as-the-rbi-governor/articleshow/67026103.cms a couple of days apparently for "personal reasons". It was his "privilege and honour" to serve in the RBI, he said, and thanked his colleagues for their "support and hard work". Pointedly he did not thank the Prime Minister, who appointed him as governor, or the Finance Minister with whom he must have interacted regularly in carrying out his duties. Patel took a strict view of bad loans at banks Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/MD7u31gNaEOOz38as20NFL/Opinion--What-the-Urjit-Patel-resignation-episode-tells-us.html , he refused any instructions on monetary policy and refused to hand over at least Rs 3.6 trillion Link: https://indianexpress.com/article/india/govt-wants-rs-3-6-lakh-crore-from-rbi-a-third-of-its-reserves-central-bank-says-no-5435504/ , over one-third, from RBI's contingency reserves. Bankers and finance companies are cheering Patel's exit Link: http://www.allbankingsolutions.com/Articles/Articles-DJ-Evergreen-loans.htm as they hope to go back to old ways of evergreening and hiding bad loans from becoming public. Patel's predecessor Prof Raghuram Rajan started the process of cleaning up public sector banks Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/vsp7RPTxjxRq9OYcOMZJhJ/How-RBI-blocked-evergreening-of-overseas-loans.html for which he was treated so discourteously by the government that he quietly left India Link: https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/Raghuram-Rajan-not-to-seek-second-term-as-RBI-Governor/article14430002.ece . Patel had a rough time at the RBI, starting with demonetisation of 86% of all currencies Link: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-37974423 in circulation in India which was thought to be a bad idea by Rajan Link: https://www.dnaindia.com/business/report-rbi-was-consulted-but-we-said-it-s-not-a-good-idea-raghuram-rajan-attacks-demonetization-again-2603968 . There were questions about why Patel did not voice his doubts about the exercise but one man who was intimately involved in the planning Link: https://thewire.in/economy/demonetisation-consultation was the Economic Affairs Secretary Shaktikanta Das. A retired IAS officer, Das has been quickly appointed the new Governor Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaktikanta_Das maybe because he can be relied upon to help the government. The last civil servant to be appointed Governor Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duvvuri_Subbarao of the RBI was Duvvuri Subbarao who was highly qualified. He was appointed in 2008 when average consumer price inflation Link: https://www.inflation.eu/inflation-rates/india/historic-inflation/cpi-inflation-india.aspx was over 8% but progressively reduced interest rate from a high of 9% in July 2008 to a low of 4.75% in April 2009 Link: https://www.myloancare.in/rbi-repo-rate/ . Congress won re-election in May and average inflation rose to over 12% in 2010. Subbarao slowly raised rate to 8% in 2012 but lowered it to 7.25% in 2013 even as inflation rose to nearly 11%. Congress was trounced in the 2014 elections, managing to win only 44 seats Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/16th_Lok_Sabha , not enough to nominate anyone for the post of Leader of the Opposition Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(India) . What are the problems confronting Prime Minister Modi? His party, the BJP lost in assembly elections in 3 Hindi states Link: https://www.livemint.com/Politics/K8uFRbxJWwXHUviU5TIwZL/BJP-jolted-2019-wide-open.html of Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Chhattisgarh. Hindi states have high population with high fertility rates so they have larger representation Link: https://niti.gov.in/content/total-fertility-rate-tfr-birth-woman in the parliament. To win these states Modi has to alleviate genuine suffering of farmers Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/pm-narendra-modi-seen-forgiving-farm-loans-as-he-seeks-to-win-back-rural-voters/articleshow/67048343.cms . However, indirect tax collections from the Goods and Services Tax will be short Link: https://www.livemint.com/Money/7hybZX5hN8J9kLFcGgUDrJ/Can-govt-make-up-for-shortfall-in-GST-revenue-collections.html by Rs 1 trillion. Having once looted the people through demonetisation Das is eminently suited to looting the RBI of its reserves. With its power to print money can the RBI go broke Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/a-question-haunting-india-can-a-central-bank-really-go-broke/articleshow/66675936.cms ? We will know soon.

Monday, December 10, 2018

Contempt for the bitter truth. Link: https://indiadying.blogspot.com/2018/12/contempt-for-bitter-truth.html

"Can a commoner allege political bias by sitting SC judge Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/can-a-commoner-allege-political-bias-by-sitting-sc-judge-and-escape-contempt-ire/articleshow/67018058.cms and escape contempt ire?" asked D Mahapatra. That would be worse than suicide. As businessman Subrata Roy found to his cost Link: https://www.dailyo.in/politics/subrata-roy-sahara-tihar-jail-sebi-vijay-mallya-lalit-modi-supreme-court-banks/story/1/10639.html when he was sent to prison for contempt for an indefinite period for ignoring an order to pay Rs 100 billion as demanded by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI), in what reeked of political persecution. Or when Times Now was fined Rs 1 billion for accidentally defaming Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/SC-asks-Times-Now-to-deposit-Rs-100-crore-before-HC-takes-up-its-appeal-in-defamation-case/articleshow/10734614.cms a retired Supreme Court judge, even after it apologized repeatedly for its mistake. Recently, retired Justice Joseph Kurien explained why he, with three of his colleagues, held apress conference in January in which they accused the then Chief Justice Link: https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/supreme-court-crisis-all-not-okay-democracy-at-stake-say-four-seniormost-judges/article10028921.ece of allocating cases to junior judges. "He said all four shared a perception that then CJI Deepak Mishra was being influenced by someone from outside and was allotting sensitive cases to benches headed by select junior SC judges perceived to have political bias." Refusing to initiate contempt proceedings against an article in the Punch, British Judge Lord Denning said, "All that we ask is those who criticise us should remember that, from the nature of our duties, we cannot reply to their criticism. We cannot enter into public controversy." Not so in India. Time and again judges have reacted with ferocity when criticised, although when a politician is the accused the reaction is very diffident. Perhaps suspicion of bias would not arise if judges concluded cases promptly, instead of dragging them forever. Last year the Supreme Court apologized to a woman for not concluding her case in 13 years Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/sc-says-sorry-to-litigant-for-13-year-delay-in-case/articleshow/61900118.cms , during which the woman had passed away. What use was this judgement? It took 20 years for a judgement in the Uphaar Cinema tragedy in which 59, mostly young people, died Link: https://thewire.in/law/twenty-years-families-uphaar-cinema-fire-victims-still-battling-justice . Having waited for 20 years parents and relatives of the dead were further humiliatedwhen one accused was freed because of his age Link: https://www.livelaw.in/uphaar-sc-gives-gopal-ansal-one-year-jail-brother-sushil-walks-free/ and another got a derisive 1 year in prison. It is in the interest of the guilty and of lawyers, who are paid eye-watering sums of money per appearance Link: https://www.legallyindia.com/the-bench-and-the-bar/revealed-delhi-rsquo-s-top-advocates-won-rsquo-t-even-touch-your-case-for-less-than-rs-5-lakh-20150908-6555 , to prolong a case till such time as witnesses have either died or have been coerced to turn hostile. But, why do judges go along with this sham? Mystery. In the same way not one politician has been convicted of the killing Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/Ejr322Pwxl1qOPs7bTayZO/1984-is-a-symptom-of-a-bigger-disease.html of thousands of Sikhs following Indira Gandhi's murder in 1984. Naturally, cheats take advantage of judicial inertia to file appeal after appeal costing the nation Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/blogs/toi-edit-page/promises-to-keep-reforming-contract-enforcement-and-dispute-resolution-is-key-to-unshackling-india/ many trillions of rupees, wrote S Pathak. Since civil servants are never punished for wasting court time by filing ridiculous appeals to deny citizens of their basic rights Link: https://www.oneindia.com/india/govt-is-biggest-litigant-faces-over-350-contempt-cases-law-ministry-2494602.html the government is the biggest litigant. Justice Kurien is right. Judges are biased. Against citizens.

Competition is good for business, except in India. Link: https://indiadying.blogspot.com/2018/12/competition-is-good-for-business-except.html

"Only a renegade economist will betray his brethren with such blasphemy that too much competition can be harmful Link: https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/KNDC7s3LABLJqnzScknxvI/Opinion--Downside-of-unbridled-competition.html ," wrote A Ranade. "This goes against the most basic axioms of economics." Provided there is no cheating and there is a level playing field, competition is essential to provide best quality at lowest prices. This has been accepted since, "Adam Smith's 'The Wealth Of Nations', the Bible of capitalism and free markets, was written almost a century before Charles Darwin's 'The Origin Of Species'". The adverse effect of excessive competition is best exemplified by app-based taxi services which enticed drivers with high commissions, that have now been reduced. "Most drivers have taken car loans and their current earnings are just not enough to pay the monthly installment." If the government interferes it will kill the business model. Until about a decade ago weaker companies were kept alive by soft loans from public sector banks and price fixing, wrote S Mukherjea. "For reasons which don't fully understand, this paradigm was disrupted a decade ago and we entered a more competitive era in Indian business Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/why-weak-eps-growth-for-india-inc-is-not-a-bad-thing-after-all/articleshow/66949293.cms wherein weaker firms were either bankrupted or forced to sell out." Pre-tax return on capital employed (ROCE) has fallen leading to a fall in growth of earnings per share (EPS). As weaker firms are swallowed up by stronger ones jobs will be lost Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/mergers-can-result-in-7-20-job-losses/articleshow/67016680.cms and wage growth will be suppressed. "Given the spate of consolidations over the last two years, there could be job losses in the range of 7-20%, depending on how identical businesses are. It could impact compensation levels if supply exceeds demand and this is driven by marker forces," said S Reddy. Private investment has fallen since 2014 when this government was elected Link: https://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/the-architecture-is-not-the-force/article25665791.ece , wrote Prof P Balakrishnan. The private sector is comprised of corporate and unincorporated, also known as the household sector. "Since 2014, after initially declining private corporate investment has shown a mild rise while household investment has fallen sharply." Resulting in a decline in total investment. which means fewer jobs. Recent demand for traffic brigade jobs in the Prime Minister's home state Link: https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/degrees-of-desperation-for-traffic-brigade-job/articleshow/66960358.cms of Gujarat shows how desperate young people are. These are not traffic police but daily wage laborers. Fear of lack of jobs means that people are spending less Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/banking/finance/banking/whats-hurting-indias-consumption-heres-what-rbi-has-to-say/articleshow/66966228.cms , wrote A Nag. Which will impact EPS, discourage private investment and lead to fewer jobs. In all this gloom there is some good news. Indians working abroad are to send $80 billion in remittances Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/nri/forex-and-remittance/india-to-retain-top-position-in-remittances-with-80-billion-world-bank/articleshow/66998062.cms , according to the World Bank. Since we alwaysrun a huge trade deficit, importing far more than we export Link: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/finance/indias-current-account-deficit-is-expected-to-widen-to-2-8-of-gdp-this-fiscal-nomura/articleshow/65458882.cms , perhaps we should export our brains. There is no competition for brains.
